JOHN SHIMKUS, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF ILLINOIS</opening> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">If I could ask all our guests today to please take their seats, and if we can get that door closed, the Committee on Environment will now come to order. The chair now recognizes himself for 5 minutes for an opening statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Today's hearing gives our panel a chance to look broadly at our nation's drinking water infrastructure and examine questions about what is necessary for the federal government to do in the way of reinvestment and rehabilitation of these systems to meet future needs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Currently, more than 51,000 community water systems treat 42 billion gallons of water for use by 299 million Americans daily.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">This water, which is used for anything from cooking and bathing in homes, factories, or offices to firefighting is delivered by publicly and privately-owned water utilities stretching over 1 million miles of pipe.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">It is really a remarkable feat of engineering that demonstrates our nation's commitment to public health and a high standard of living.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">For more than a decade, there have been concerns raised about this system and whether our nation is making the choices it needs to make in order to ensure effective and efficient delivery of safe drinking water in the future.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Many of the pipes now in use were installed in the early and mid-20th century and have a projected lifespan of 75 to 100 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">In 2013, the EPA announced that a bit more than $384 million of investment was needed between 2010 and 2030 to improve drinking water infrastructure and ensure the provision of safe tap water.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">This report was not a suggestion that the federal government needed to provide all of that funding but it and other reports have served as a wake-up call to the threat facing these systems and begs the question as to whether Congress should be doing more.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Before the Safe Drinking Water Act Amendments of 1996, to the extent that it was needed, Congress' role in financing drinking water infrastructure was confined to line items for specific projects, a practice that has been substantially curtailed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">In 1996, Congress, realizing the biggest economic problem facing drinking water systems was the cost of unfunded mandates, created a State Revolving Loan Fund program to provide low-interest loans that helped address compliance and public health needs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Last year, the Water Infrastructure Improvements for the Nation Act authorized $600 million between two new programs dedicated to tackling lead pipe replacement and aiding economically disadvantaged and underserved communities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">In addition, this law tried to further invigorate loans not related to Drinking Water Act compliance through the Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">While I think these are solid steps, we must also reauthorize funding for the Drinking Water Revolving Loan Fund program. This has been a very successful and important program whose purpose is synergistic in view of other infrastructure programs, having provided more than $20 billion in funding to over 12,400 projects since 1997.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We must also explore other avenues that not only leverage investments in these utility infrastructures but also do it in a way that promotes American workers and protect consumers' health and pocketbooks.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We need to be smart about our investments. This is not going to be an easy discussion, but to be successful it is one we must have.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">I believe we must not be afraid to spend more federal money on this issue, but we must maintain local fees as the primary generator of funds for daily operation and maintenance of public water systems as well as their long-term capital investment needs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">That said, we must acknowledge that not only as a percentage of household income, U.S. households pay less for water and wastewater than other developed countries and that water rates have dropped 3 percent more recently.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We also must remember that some systems have taken the very unpopular step of raising rates.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">But not everyone can do that, whether due to population contraction or local economic condition, because their rate bases aren't able to handle capital improvements as well as others do.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">So long as we focus on trying to increase overall purchasing power for communities, our constituents can enjoy their drinking water for the next 75 to 100 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Before I relinquish my time, I want to thank our witnesses for being here today, especially in view of the crazy weather and travel schedules that you and we have had.</paragraph>

<opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. PAUL TONKO, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF NEW YORK</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. PAUL TONKO"> The chair now recognizes the ranking member, Mr. Tonko, for 5 minutes, who has an interest in this issue. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Thank you, Mr. Chair. Thank you, and Chair Walden for holding this hearing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I know I sound like a broken record requesting a drinking water hearing for the past 4 years but I am truly grateful to you for bringing us together today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I also want to thank our experts here for being in attendance. We will hear from all of them, from water utilities to engineers to environmental stakeholders that our national drinking water infrastructure needs are immense.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I also understand that they will present formally their report card on infrastructure. I can tell you, if I received a report card like that my parents would have had a response immediately.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Tonko">They would have had an improvement plan in place immediately. So let's get going, nation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Tonko">The facts are startling. We lose over 2 trillion gallons of treated water each year from leaking pipes. There are more than 240,000 water main breaks each year, which causes service disruption and property damage.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Nearly 100 mid-size cities across our great country are facing shrinking populations, meaning a smaller taxpayer base, to support repairs and to support maintenance.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Tonko">As Mr. DiLoreto will explain, the American Society of Civil Engineers recently released their report card and have given our systems a grade of D.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Tonko">It is clear we are not making the progress necessary to tackle this issue. If anything, we are going in the wrong direction. EPA has estimated some $384 billion is needed over the next 20 years to keep our systems running.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Tonko">And as we deal with aging systems, often with century-old pipes and an alarming number of unregulated and under regulated contaminants, this estimate can only be expected to grow.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Tonko">The bottom line is I do not see how the needs can be met without significantly greater federal investments. I feel the need to say that the proposed cuts to EPA outlined in President Trump's budget are not only senseless, they are dangerous.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Tonko">While funding levels for the SRFs appear to be maintained, the status quo is simply not good enough. We need additional funding.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Tonko">For example, in my home state of New York, we receive a generous allotment from the Drinking Water SRF--about $40 annually. That money is leveraged with state funds which may allow for about $700 million in projects this year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Tonko">The problem is there were over $4 billion worth of projects requested, according to this year's intended use plan. Projects that are not funded will continue to be deferred, putting more stress on already struggling systems.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Tonko">So even for a state that is committed to addressing this issue, there is still a tremendous gap between available funds and needs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Tonko">We cannot fool ourselves into thinking local and state governments can do this on their own. There is a federal responsibility. This infrastructure is too important to continue to be neglected.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Tonko">And let us make no mistake, there are real consequences-- health and economic--when these systems fail. Flint should have been a wake-up call to Congress that we must do more.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Tonko">The investments we can make now are minuscule when compared to the cost of inaction. And Flint is not alone. These problems lurk below the surface throughout our country.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Here are just a few headlines from this past week.
